title: The advantages and pitfalls of elicitated online user engagement
descriptions:
This grant proposal seeks to investigate the advantages and pitfalls of elicited online user engagement, focusing on the impact of calls to action on websites from both business and societal perspectives. The project will utilize an empirical approach, including lab and field experiments, to achieve the following objectives: understanding user engagement and its elicitation, determining the direct value of user engagement for businesses, assessing societal implications, characterizing effects in various product domains, and isolating underlying mechanisms of calls to action.

Preliminary results suggest that calls to action have significant effects on both conversion rates and information revelation. The project will collaborate with a leading website-development service provider with a freemium business model to ensure the relevance and applicability of the research findings. 

The anticipated impact of this project includes enhancing economic and societal understanding of social computing, providing valuable insights for businesses and policymakers. By shedding light on the dynamics of online user engagement, this research has the potential to inform strategies for website optimization, marketing campaigns, and user interaction design in the digital age.

The proposed project, titled "The advantages and pitfalls of elicitated online user engagement," aims to investigate the impact of user engagement elicited by calls to action on websites from both business and societal perspectives. The project will utilize an empirical approach, including lab and field experiments, to achieve its objectives, which include understanding user engagement and its elicitation, determining the direct value of user engagement for businesses, assessing societal implications, characterizing effects in multiple product domains, and isolating underlying mechanisms of calls to action.

Preliminary results suggest that calls to action have strong effects on both conversion rates and information revelation. The project will collaborate with a leading website-development service provider operating on a freemium business model. The anticipated impact of the study includes advancing economic and societal understanding of social computing.

Overall, this project will contribute valuable insights into the role of user engagement in online interactions, shedding light on the advantages and pitfalls of calls to action for businesses and society. By bridging the gap between theory and practice, the findings of this research have the potential to inform website development strategies and optimize user engagement efforts in the digital realm.

The proposed project, "The advantages and pitfalls of elicitated online user engagement," aims to investigate the impact of user engagement elicited by calls to action on websites from both business and societal perspectives. Using an empirical approach, the project will conduct lab and field experiments to achieve several objectives, including understanding user engagement and its elicitation, determining the direct value of user engagement for businesses, assessing societal implications, characterizing effects in different product domains, and isolating underlying mechanisms of calls to action.

Preliminary results suggest that calls to action have strong effects on conversion and information revelation. The project will collaborate with a leading website-development service provider operating on a freemium business model. Anticipated impacts of this research include enhancing economic and societal understanding of social computing.

Overall, this project will provide valuable insights into the dynamics of online user engagement and its implications for businesses and society. By shedding light on the advantages and pitfalls of calls to action, the findings from this research have the potential to inform website development strategies and contribute to a deeper understanding of the role of user engagement in the digital landscape.
